 Speaking only of the US, I think most of those past inheritance issues involving legitimacy, paternalism and other social circumstances have been resolved by our legal system. That's not saying one is automatically exempt from historical customs affecting legal decisions on a precedent basis without engaging private legal counsel to direct estate assets in a defined manner, because it does require that effort.
 
 In most cases a simple will directing assets to non-family beneficiaries, be it holographic or formally executed by counsel, can be successfully challenged by a blood relative of a deceased based on historical traditions and precedent rulings. While I believe this is a just system for a majority of circumstances, there are always exceptions for a variety of reasons. 
 
 To exclude a child or other blood relative from participation in a division of assets left by death or restrict that person's access to capital (such as interest only bequests with the capital remaining in trust) or include a substantial non-family bequest requires a series of well-defined declarations in the will and they must be supported in the trust. In most cases that expertise is not available from legal counsel unless they specialize in trust law, which generally requires accompanying expertise in real property and finance tax law. People desiring inheritance exclusions often make the mistake of engaging counsel not qualified to construct viable documents. In this case you get what you pay for is the rule of thumb. If a trust lawyer has to advertise for business, the required expertise probably isn't going to be there.
 
 When the will and trust are in place, complete with booby-traps to discourage legal challenges, a competent trust lawyer will require periodic follow-up to establish sound of mind status to reinforce intent and eliminate emotion. That's normally done at six month, one year and 18-month intervals and consists of the individual, together in the case of a husband and wife, being interviewed by the attorney and two other attorneys as a council with questions relating to intent and mental capacity, all recorded and sworn to by the participants. When completed, the will and trust are then considered bullet-proof. 
 
 Tradition is a no-brainer comfort level for many people, especially those with minds set in stone, and it does die hard.

The important issue is that the tools are there, but the individual(s) must make the effort, and bear the expense, to use them. That eliminates probably 90% of estate holders, primarily on the bottom end of the economic scale. Otherwise a majority of civil legal rulings are made on precendent rulings, some hundreds of years old. 
 
 One common tool for exclusion of a blood heir from estate proceeds is to will them a token amount, $1, to recognize their legitimacy and directly address intent. That's somewhat cosmetic and sates tradition for legal purposes. 
 
 Tradition also breeds complacency and many formal will readings have resulted in near-violence when assuming heirs of substantial estates discovered their inheritance had been legally redirected. For that reason copies of wills/trusts are now generally delivered to counsel of all interested parties, an additional break from tradition.
